I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $50,000,000 or its yuan equivalent to Henan Tian Lun Gas Group Limited (HTL) for the 
Henan Tian Lun Resilient Energy Supply Project in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2.  The project will support a private sector company contributing to air pollution mitigation 
alongside the Air Quality Improvement in the Greater Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei (BTH) Region—
Henan Cleaner Fuel Switch Investment Program of the East Asia Department (EARD).1 The 
project will support HTL’s efforts to supply sustained last-mile city natural gas to residential, 
commercial, and industrial end users in Henan Province. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Project identification. In the PRC, natural gas plays an important role as a cleaner and 
lower carbon emitting alternative to coal, which remains a dominant component of the primary 
energy and electricity generation mix. Fuel switching is a policy priority of the government to 
address chronic air pollution. Natural gas is consumed by residential consumers primarily for 
heating and cooking, and by commercial and industrial consumers in power and heat generation 
and in industrial processes. When it is made available to end users, natural gas can directly 
replace coal consumption and/or displace predominantly coal-generated grid electricity. 
 
4.  Under a One Asian Development Bank (ADB) approach, the Private Sector Operations 
Department (PSOD) identified HTL as a private sector company supplying natural gas in the 
urban areas of Henan Province during the processing of the Air Quality Improvement in the 
Greater BTH Region—Henan Cleaner Fuel Switch Investment Program led by EARD. HTL jointly 
operates Yu-Tian New Energy Company Limited, the company that will be an implementation 
agent for the fuel switching program, and which will provide last-mile natural gas connections to 
end-users in the BTH region. PSOD followed up with HTL to support with a private sector solution 
contributing to sustainable air quality improvement. Faced with prolonging energy bill payment 
delays from its customers, HTL requested that ADB provide a facility to help meet working capital 
needs, thereby ensuring its financial sustainability and capacity to sustain uninterrupted natural 
gas supplies in Henan Province. 
 
5.  To enhance the resilience of cities, the Government of the PRC issued directives urging 
providers of essential utility services to ensure the uninterrupted supply of electricity, gas, and 
heating,  while  concurrently  extending  consumers’  payment  terms.  [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED] The purpose of the government directives is to support consumers of 
essential utility services, who experienced a severe economic shock due to pandemic lockdowns, 
in recovering economically. While the directives are effective, HTL still needs to pay for the 
procurement of natural gas supplies at the city gate. It is expected that these directives will remain 
in effect through at least the end of 2021, with increasing numbers of end users being sold energy 
supplies on extended payment terms, leading to increased working capital needs for essential 
utilities. 
 
 
1  ADB. 2021. Proposed Results Based Loan, People’s Republic of China: Air Quality Improvement in the Greater 
Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei Region—Henan Cleaner Fuel Switch Investment Program. Manila (52007-001-PRC).

2 
6.  As an essential utility, HTL has been directed to sustain service provision, notwithstanding 
the extension of payment terms for its customers. HTL, as a last-mile city gas distributor, has to 
pay for procured gas at the city gate as it is supplied, and earns only a regulated margin on 
volumes from end users inside cities, which have been delayed in receipt as they are subject to 
the extended billing cycle. As a result, HTL faces an estimated net working capital increase 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED]. 
 
7.  Project design. The loan will support HTL’s natural gas distribution operations for about 
510,000 residential and business customers in Henan Province. This will help HTL and five 
operating subsidiaries2 ensure timely, uninterrupted procurement of upstream energy supplies for 
distribution to end users through existing distribution networks within each subsidiary’s operating 
footprint, even as outstanding bills from those end users grow. 
 
8.  Sustained and reliable delivery of natural gas through this project will help households, 
commercial, and industrial end users reduce fuel expenditure, save time because of more efficient 
cooking and heating, improve respiratory health. A disruption in local natural gas supplies will lead 
to an increasing likelihood of end users having to rely on alternative energy sources including 
predominantly coal-generated grid electricity and would also discourage adoption of natural gas 
as a cleaner fuel alternative which would negatively impact air pollution and the adoption of 
climate change mitigating infrastructure investments in the region. 
 
9.  Gender  context.  While  the  PRC’s  growth  and  development  have  led  to  notable 
socioeconomic progress, gender inequality has been increasing. Social transformation in the PRC 
has resulted in a gender gap in the labor market and intensified conflict between work and family 
as traditional views of gender roles persist. Women spend an average of almost 4 hours per day 
on unpaid care work, 2.5 times more time than men. The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic has aggravated these inequalities faced by women who are juggling work with added 
domestic duties, which multiplies if a family member becomes sick.3 Access to clean energy 
sources is likely to have a positive impact on the health and well-being of women.4 Use of modern 
fuels such as gas for cooking can reduce women’s work and time burden and reduce indoor and 
outdoor pollution. The time saved can be used by women to improve their and their families’ lives 
through education, income generation, or leisure.5 
 
10.  Sponsor and guarantor. Headquartered in Henan Province, PRC, China Tian Lun Gas 
Holdings  Limited  (CTL),  the  project  sponsor  and  guarantor,  is  a  private  sector  company 
incorporated in the Cayman Islands and is listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange6. It began 
operations  in  2004,  following  the  government's  2002  policy  decision  to  open  natural  gas 
distribution to private sector participation. It was one of the earliest non-state-owned enterprises 
in the urban gas sector in the PRC. CTL’s primary activities are constructing and operating city 
gas pipelines and supplying natural gas to residential, commercial, and industrial end users

Ltd., Henan Tianlun Gas Pipe Network Co., Ltd., Xiping Kaida Gas Co., Ltd. and Shenqiu County Huixin Natural Gas 
Co., Ltd.

through  its  wholly  owned  subsidiary  HTL.  Other  business  lines  include  engineering  and 
construction of gas distribution infrastructure and long-haul gas transmission pipelines. Recently, 
CTL has focused on fuel switching, substituting coal and coal gas for natural gas. CTL is one of 
the largest gas distribution companies in Henan Province and has a substantial presence in 13 
provinces across the PRC. CTL manages itself and HTL in accordance with the mandatory 
requirements of corporate governance norms specified by the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Its 
governance structure broadly comprises the board of directors and the committees of the board 
at the group level, and the senior management at the operational level. The board of directors 
comprises  four  executive  directors  and four  independent  directors.  CTL  also  has  a  highly 
experienced management team with technical and financial capabilities. Responsibilities and 
authorities are clearly divided between management and the board of directors. 
 
11.  Borrower. The borrower is HTL, a wholly owned subsidiary of CTL incorporated in 2004 
in the PRC, contributing 97% of CTL’s total revenues. As of fiscal year (FY) 2019, HTL had 23 
urban gas projects and one long-haul transmission pipeline in Henan Province, four urban gas 
projects in Shandong Province, and two urban gas projects in both Gansu Province and Sichuan 
Province. The company is the largest provider of piped gas in Henan Province and is connected 
to 3.2 million residential consumers and more than 23,000 industrial and commercial users. 
Revenues are primarily derived from city gas sales, installation fees, and long-haul pipeline gas 
sales. As of FY2019, HTL reported total assets of CNY11.31 billion, and revenues of CNY6.37 
billion. 
 
12.  Integrity  due  diligence.  ADB  conducted  integrity  due  diligence. 7  HTL,  CTL,  its 
shareholders, ultimate beneficial owners, and board of directors do not appear to constitute a 
significant or potentially significant integrity risk, as no unresolved adverse media or other relevant 
integrity-related information is associated with them. ADB’s review of HTL and CTL does not give 
ADB cause to believe that it is being used for money laundering or terrorism financing. 
 
13.  Tax integrity due diligence. ADB conducted tax integrity due diligence.8 ADB obtained 
reasonable assurance that the transaction is not being used for tax secrecy, tax evasion, or tax 
fraud. 
 
14.  Pandemic impacts. The government’s essential utility directive has led to a sharp 
increase in reported receivables for HTL: 44 days as of FY2019 to 75 days as of H12020. This 
additional latitude in payment terms is being provided by HTL following the government’s essential 
utilities directive to support the post-pandemic recovery. In financial terms, HTL’s accounts 
receivables were reported at CNY776 million at the end of 2019, having increased to CNY1,219 
million as of H12020 [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED]. HTL is seeking to mitigate the 
increased working capital requirement through ADB’s financing of the project. 
 
B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
15.  Impact. The project will support economic and social activities in Henan Province to 
continue.

16.  Outcome. The project will support the continuity of economic and social activities using 
natural gas in Henan Province.  
 
17.  Outputs. The project will have the following outputs: (i) natural gas supplied to residents 
and businesses in cities in Henan Province on credit sustained, (ii) supply of natural gas on credit 
and favorable terms for households with a single mother in Henan Province sustained, (iii) 
supplies of basic child and maternal necessities to households with a single mother in Henan 
Province supported, and (iv) knowledge sharing related to the clean energy transition in the PRC 
increased. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
18.  Consistency with ADB’s strategy and country strategy. The project is aligned with 
ADB’s  Strategy  2030  operational  priority  2  (accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality)  and 
operational priority 4 (making cities more livable).9 HTL’s Single Mother Care Action program, 
which will be implemented until the end of 2023 in line with the agreed ADB gender action plan 
(GAP), directly addresses the economic and social welfare of households with a single mother 
supplied by HTL’s distribution network. Ensuring the supply of natural gas will mitigate urban air 
pollution and enhance the resilience of cities as they continue to recover from the economic 
impacts of the pandemic. The provision of gas to meet basic energy demand contributes to 
building livable cities by providing uninterrupted access to energy in urban areas and surrounding 
communities. No climate mitigation or adaptation financing has been estimated for this project. 
 
19.  PRC country partnership strategy. The project addresses the first strategic priority of 
ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for  the  PRC,  2021–2025,10 which  calls  for  supporting 
environmentally sustainable development and health security through private sector solutions, 
including last-mile connectivity and cleaner fuels (para. 36[iii] of the country partnership strategy). 
 
20.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project embodies 
ADB’s Operational Plan for Private Sector Operations, 2019–2024,11 and ADB's Energy Policy,12 
which emphasizes energy security and universal access to energy. The policies encourage ADB 
to help developing member countries provide reliable, adequate, and affordable energy for 
inclusive growth in a socially, economically, and environmentally sustainable way. 
 
21.  Lessons  from  previous  operations.  Key  lessons  from  past  interventions  include 
(i) working with the last-mile service deliverer as a change agent for access to vulnerable 
households,13 (ii)  identifying  best-in-class  technical  operators  (from  the  public  and  private 
sectors)  capable  of  integrating  complex  gas  distribution  logistics,  (iii)  developing  a  good 
understanding of national and regional regulations to promote access to energy for different end 
users’ needs, and (iv) supporting transparency of the full gas distribution value chain, including

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
26.  ADB will provide a loan of up to $50,000,000 or its yuan equivalent to fund HTL’s working 
capital requirements for purchases of natural gas in Henan Province from 2021 to 2023. ADB’s 
loan will have a 2-year tenor, 2-year weighted average life, and bullet repayment. The covenant 
package will be aligned with market standards to the borrower, will be unsecured, and will be 
guaranteed by the listed parent company, CTL. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
27.  Financial additionality. ADB’s assistance is designed to fill a gap in the local financial 
market. HTL relies heavily on up to 1-year working capital facilities that are subject to monthly 
liquidity quota allocations, which can make urgently needed funds suddenly unavailable for 
drawdown. Any longer-term financing HTL can procure is typically associated with fixed asset 
investment or acquisition and must be secured and specifically tied to that use of proceeds 
accordingly. ADB’s 2-year unsecured bullet facility will greatly enhance HTL’s financial flexibility 
as (i) it is a firmly committed loan that will not become unavailable because of tight local lending 
market liquidity; (ii) it has a longer tenor than typical working capital facilities in the PRC market, 
with back-ended bullet maturity that can accommodate the timing uncertainty associated with 
prolonged end user payment delays; and (iii) it does not require additional security which is limited 
and HTL needs to make available for longer term capex financing. 
 
28.  Nonfinancial additionality. ADB’s engagement with this project will promote gender 
inclusiveness in HTL’s operations through the agreed GAP. Building upon EARD’s previous 
support for corporate governance and environmental and social management system (ESMS) 
enhancement,  ADB  provides  a  corporate-wide  ESMS  audit  and  supports  HTL  in  the 
implementation of robust environmental, social, and health management practices. Finally, with 
ADB Energy Sector Group technical expertise and a knowledge-sharing workshop, the project 
will support HTL in developing a corporate strategy aligned with the PRC clean energy transition. 
Any relevant learnings from the workshop will be disseminated to other developing member 
countries and stakeholders as appropriate.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
35.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) as follows: environment (category C), involuntary resettlement (category C), 
and indigenous peoples (category C).16 
36.  ADB has undertaken due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social 
impacts of the project and measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse 
impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. The environmental and social measures and the 
institutional capacity and commitment of HTL to manage the project’s social and environmental 
 
16 ADB. Safeguard Categories.

7 
impacts are deemed adequate. The loan will be for working capital purposes only and will not be 
used to fund any new or ongoing projects that involve permanent or temporary land acquisition; 
any retrofits, rehabilitation, or expansion projects; or any activities that may directly or indirectly 
affect indigenous peoples or vulnerable ethnic minorities or scheduled tribes. The project activities 
are likely to have no adverse additional environmental impacts. 
 
37.  The International Finance Corporation (IFC) invested in CTL for a project in 2015 and 
prescribed an environmental and social action plan.17 As CTL had an ESMS in place at the time, 
the action plan focused on the establishment of a corporate-level environment, health, and safety 
(EHS) department and the development of new quantitative risk assessment and risk audit 
policies and procedures. IFC reported in its public disclosure that the company had completed all 
tasks by January 2016. The implementing agency for the ADB 2019 sovereign program loan 
involving CTL (Henan Yu-Tian New Energy Co. Ltd.) is a joint venture company established by 
HTL and a state-owned enterprise under the Henan Provincial Finance Bureau. HTL owns 40% 
of the joint venture company, which utilizes HTL personnel and infrastructure. The loan supports 
the transition from coal to cleaner fuel for residential, commercial, and industrial users in select 
less-developed  counties  of  Henan  Province  by  expanding  the  gas  pipeline  network  and 
developing a new alternative clean fuel biogas plant. Following ADB’s extensive environmental 
and social due diligence, the project was placed in category B for environment and involuntary 
resettlement and category C for indigenous peoples. Through meetings with IFC and ADB 
sovereign counterparts, review of reporting to IFC and ADB, and assessment of the ESMS and 
other operational procedures, ADB’s due diligence found that HTL is operating in conformance 
with agreed and applicable requirements. 
 
38.  HTL operates in accordance with the ESMS followed by all CTL subsidiaries, which 
includes EHS and stakeholder engagement policies and procedures for managing aspects of its 
operations that meet regulatory requirements and IFC’s Performance Standards. CTL has a 
corporate-level  EHS  department  responsible  for  safety  management,  environmental  and 
occupational health management, stakeholder engagement, production operation management, 
and loss management for existing operations and potential large projects. Through the EHS 
department, HTL proactively identifies potential health and safety risks in the workplace to 
continuously improve occupational health management and to ensure that employees understand 
the relevant risks and response measures. CTL publishes an annual environmental, social, and 
governance report in which it publicly discloses its EHS performance in the preceding year. The 
2019  annual  report  includes  coverage  of  personnel  safety  training  for  construction  and 
improvements in safety management levels generally. HTL is also undergoing recertification for 
ISO 9001 (Quality Management System) and OHSAS 18001 (Occupational Health and Safety 
Management System). 
 
39.  Effective  gender  mainstreaming.  Single  mothers  represent  70%  of  single-parent 
households in the PRC. A 2020 study found that most single mothers had incomes that were not 
sufficient  to  meet  daily  expenses;  they  lacked  social  safety  nets,  had  low  wages,  limited 
employment opportunities, and significant time-poverty, which increased the probability of them 
falling into extreme poverty. The COVID-19 pandemic has aggravated these inequalities (footnote 
4). Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (2003), HTL has incorporated measures 
to promote gender equality and/or women’s empowerment in its business activities. Key features 
of the GAP are (i) at least 8,700 households with a single mother will be continuously supplied 
with natural gas until the end of 2022 on favorable payment terms, including a 10% discount and 
an  additional  2-month  delay  in  payment  due  date;  and  (ii)  supplies  of  child  and  early

childcare/nutrition products (including milk, bottles, and diapers) for at least 8,700 households 
with a single mother. Households with children below the age of 3 will benefit from these 
measures. HTL will submit periodic reports on implementation of gender measures to ADB. 
 
40.  HTL will (i) apply ADB's prohibited investment activities list, (ii) ensure that investments 
using ADB funds comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), and (iii) abide by 
applicable  national  laws  and  regulations.  HTL  human  resource  management  policies  and 
procedures  ensure  it  operates  in  accordance  with  national  labor  laws  and  internationally 
recognized core labor standards, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy (2001). HTL’s 
stakeholder  management  system  contains  requirements  for  information  disclosure  and 
consultation  with  affected  people  following  national  requirements  that  conform  with  ADB’s 
requirements for the loan. HTL will report regularly to ADB on (i) its compliance with such laws 
and (ii) the measures taken.18 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
41.  HTL was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
43.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),19 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of the 
PRC has no objection to the proposed assistance to HTL. ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
44.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$50,000,000 or its yuan equivalent from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Henan Tian Lun Gas 
Group Limited for the Henan Tian Lun Resilient Energy Supply Project in the People’s Republic 
of China, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth 
in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.

metadata.Subject: The project will support a private sector company contributing to air pollution mitigation alongside the Air Quality Improvement in the Greater Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei (BTH) Region— Henan Cleaner Fuel Switch Investment Program of the East Asia Department (EARD). The project will support Henan Tian Lun Gas Group Limited's efforts to supply sustained last-mile city natural gas to residential, commercial, and industrial end users in Henan Province.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated May 2021 is provided for the ADB project 54359-001 in the People's Republic of China.
